Repository Factory Presentation Slides

Posted by davidhayden on October 21, 2007

I presented the Repository Factory at the Tampa .NET Developer Group on Thursday and made the presentation slides available here.


Most of the time was spent creating a data access layer from scratch from an existing database as well as walking through the code that it generates. You can get the same experience from the two screencasts:




  • Create Data Access Layer Using Repository Factory Guidance Package Screencast


  • Repository Factory Guidance Package Code Walkthrough Screencast

Two pieces of feedback were:




  • Wish it generated VB Code


  • Wish it would save settings and re-generate all code without having to redo all steps again and again

Perhaps the community may tackle a VB version. This is probably simpler than one would think as most of the effort would be modifying the T4 Templates.


As far as ease of code generation similar to CodeSmith, CodeBreeze, or MyGeneration, you would probably be better off just using those tools and ouputting similar code. I did the same thing with my own code generator:




  • My Code Generator Now Generates Repository Factory Data Access Layer Classes

 and even added support for views and stored procedure wrappers.


As discussed, the strengths of the Repository Factory are also its weaknesses. Per my slides:


Pros:




  • Simple O/R Mapper – Pure ADO.NET using SPROCS



    • No Reflection and No Database Schema Tricks


    • No Special Conventions or Performance Gotchas


    • No Attributes, Base Classes, Mapping Files


    • Easy to Maintain, Support, and Understand


  • Multi-Database Support



    • Via Data Access Application Block


  • Comes With Source Code and Templates

 Cons:




  • Not A Complete O/R Mapper



    • No Lazy Loading or Eager Loading


    • No Relationship Support- 1:1, 1:m, m:m


    • No Object State Tracking


    • Currency Support Only via Timestamp


  • Now Community Led Development



    • P&P No Longer Involved In Development

 


If you are new to O/R Mapping, the Repository Factory is a gentle way to get started as it still uses SPROCS and the code is pure ADO.NET. As you start to better understand and embrace O/R Mapping, you will probably desire more functionality. LINQ To SQL and the ADO.NET Entity Framework are real alternatives that you can use in the not so distance future.
